terms.definition: User-facing manuals and guides that explain the workflow and user interface of a product, designed for end users with minimal technical knowledge.
Technical documentation covering the underlying technologies, prerequisites, and configurable attributes of a software product for IT administrators and developers.
A centralized, authoritative source of information that IT personnel can refer to for accurate and up-to-date documentation.
Application Programming Interface - a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate and integrate with each other.
The specific group of users for whom documentation is written, such as end users for product docs or developers for technical docs.
The visual elements and controls through which users interact with a software application or product.
External software components, libraries, or systems that a software application requires to function properly.
A text-based interface where users can execute commands and interact with software using typed instructions rather than graphical elements.
The primary branch or version of software where finalized code changes are merged and distributed to users.
Individual changes or updates to code that are saved and tracked in a version control system.
To mark software features or functions as outdated and discourage their use, often before removing them in future versions.
The arrangement and interconnection of network components, describing how different parts of a system communicate.
Specialized terminology and language used by professionals in technical fields that may be difficult for general users to understand.
The systematic process of identifying, diagnosing, and resolving problems or issues in software systems.
The process of reviewing and testing documentation or software to ensure it meets standards and functions correctly before release.
